pros: I’ve never worked at an organization that has so many people who are truly here for our mission — and that includes the clinicians in the clinics and my higher-ups. Something I’ve learned in my time here is that our organization is very complex, and that complexity requires us to work together, improve our systems and keep improving…all so we can help improve health for the people we serve. I think that the organization has done a solid job of balancing our commitment to “doing” with our commitment to building the infrastructure we need to do things well. I was also inspired by our recent staff survey that showed the vast majority of us feeling this way. I’m reading some of the other posts, and feel the need to counter with some actual information to help paint a more accurate picture. Of a survey that was put out to 750 of us…96% of us said that we’re proud to work at Americares. 97% feel that our work furthers the organization. 91% of us enjoy our daily work. 89% believe the leadership team is building a strong future for Americares. And 87% feel we are building an inclusive environment for all staff. (Management, I’m sorry if this was meant for staff only—but it’s amazing, and something to celebrate!)
cons: In our efforts to balance the “doing” and the “building,” it can be hard to get everyone on board with decisions to prioritize. But even when I don’t have a project funded or an idea implemented, I still feel I was heard and respected.

pros: Americares has been one of the best experiences of my life. It is a global organization that always cares about its employees and about having a pleasant and respectful work environment. It is currently reaching 10 cities in Colombia to serve migrants, especially from Venezuela. The social cause is beautiful and the impact that its programs have alleviates the already difficult living conditions that they face when migrating. The staff who attend the clinics have a beautiful vocation for service that patients always appreciate and that they express in congratulatory notes that they leave anonymously in the different media that are available for quality effects. The suggestion box and the anonymous lines to make comments to Head Quarters are valuable tools to find out their opinions, they all account for this type of expression of gratitude and affection and, in any case, they are always a primary source of information to monitor the operation and implement their suggestions in the permanent improvement of services to the population. I must say that salary is very competitive and is even above market conditions in Colombia. Thank you Americares for all the great things you do every day and for everything you have given me.
cons: Being a global big size organization, we are still facing challenges in triyng to keep all countries more close from each other. There will always be space for improvement and we are working hard to get it.

review_title: A good place to "get your feet wet" in international assistance before moving on to a more developmentally focused NGO.
pros: Among NGOs that provide in-kind medical donations, AmeriCares is a leader in the field for the quality and volume of donations distributed. The organization has a history of being among the first to deliver assistance both internationally and within the USA when disaster strikes. Unknown to most is that AmeriCares does much more than disaster response. Much of AmeriCares assistance helps support on-going healthcare programs overseas managed by local charitable organizations who, without AmeriCares donations, would have difficulty delivering critical healthcare in many of the world's poorest regions. Additionally, AmeriCares implements three important domestic programs:  providing free medical care for the uninsured, organizing teams of volunteers to carry out critical home repairs for the poor and elderly, and providing a summer camp experience annually for HIV/AIDS affected children.  Staff at AmeriCares are generally young, enthusiastic and dedicated. AmeriCares gives many their first opportunity to work in a humanitarian organization with international  and domestic activities.
cons: For individuals interested in a career in international health, there is little actual healthcare programming that takes place as the primary task for managers and associates in the Program Department involves assigning the medical donations that AmeriCares has received to the various partner agencies overseas, ensuring that these donations are shipped in a timely manner and that partners notify AmeriCares when shipments arrive. At times, international assistance work at AmeriCares can seem more like the operations of  shipping company such as UPS, though with loftier goals.

Almost all of the money given is used for goods.  The percentage of money that is used for administration is minimal compared to many non profits.   You have a good feeling when you work here.

The only downside is that when donations are down, the organization cannot do as much for others and when they had to let people go save on funds,  some experienced people were let go and severance was minimal although the organization offered some time of re-employment workshops.  I think that we were such a close group, I am sure that the environment has changed and it will be a while before things get somewhat back to normal.  I wish them well. thanks

pros:
AmeriCares has an infectiously positive atmosphere. It's hard to walk in the front doors and not be inspired by something that someone is working on. I have felt completely supported in every aspect of my role, from onboarding to reaching out to individuals I'm interested in learning more about to diving deep into my work and making changes to systems that don't make sense to my style of work. 

I think one of the best pieces of coming into my role at AmeriCares was the onboarding - I have never come into a role where I had orientations set up with departments across the organization to help me understand what the mission as a whole looks like. You also have the chance to sit down with the CEO for breakfast and just talk to him, ask questions about the organization and his vision for its future - it's truly phenomenal. And as my role also directly oversees onboarding, I'm excited at the opportunity to expand this and make it even more comprehensive!
cons: I wouldn't necessarily say there are any "cons" per se, but one challenge I've faced is that the organizational culture is more meeting heavy than I have ever been used to. Again, I don't think this is a problem or that it's overly meeting heavy; it's just something that I'm experiencing for the first time.

pros: AmeriCares is a great organization and working there this spring has been one of the best experiences that I have ever had. From the moment I walked in to interview, I felt comfortable and very welcomed and I knew that this was going to be a good fit for me. Everyone is very friendly and welcoming and it did not take me long to feel like I am a part of the organization. I worked in the Human Resources Department and my internship was a great learning experience where I was given real assignments and responsibilities to accomplish. I also had a wonderful manager that gave me the opportunity to shadow a lot of the work she does, gave me meaningful work, and was available to answer any questions I had along the process. I was included in the weekly all staff meetings which was a great way for me to learn about the work the organization was doing in the U.S and all over the world. It's a great working environment overall and it's clear that all employees are dedicated to the AmeriCares mission. It was truly an honor working with such wonderful and intelligent people!
cons: I can't think of a single negative thing to write about AmeriCaes. I guess as an intern, I would have preferred a paid internship, especially because I had to take the train but it was totally worth it.

pros: The organization itself does great work, and the staff on the program side enjoys the opportunities they get to travel and engage internationally.
cons: The promotion structure is based on time, not ability, meaning many of the people in charge are absolutely terrible managers, but since they've been there a while they end up in positions of power. Equally bad is the inability of entry-level employees to move up in duties and responsibilities. After three years you should expect to be doing exactly the same things you were doing on day one, no matter how much you prove yourself or how invaluable you become to your team. Then either accept it or quit - like most people do when they realize they're not going anywhere. Every other week they announce a new departure, but no one in HR seems to care about what's causing that - people are disposable.

pros: I have been working here for several years now. Currently, this organization is going through a positive, revolutionary transition. With the advent of a new CEO in the beginning of 2014, I believe that evolution will catalyze faster. AmeriCares is slowly transitioning from a medical aid and humanitarian aid organization to a more development and program oriented organization, still maintaining its emergency response and  humanitarian aid as its strongest base. This is a place to work if you have a passion to work in the humanitarian development and global health fields. People here love what they do, they are an energetic, passionate bunch who truly care. Apart from that, friendly community, great work-life balance especially for females.
cons: Some departments can seem a little disconnect with the overall mission of this organization. But the higher management is working on regular communication and education.
